bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, January 13, 1876

div1.p: Reed teases Emilie Lawrence about not writing and about attentions from Professor Sharpe. He discusses small pox cases among children on the post.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, January 13, 1876

opener.dateline:
Willet's Point,
New York Harbor,
Jan. 13rd 76.

div1.p:
I could but
smile when I read the first
few lines of your letter- In
writing to you, I had begun my
letter by deploring the delay in
receiving yours; & lo! behold,
in commencing yours, you have
given expression to the same
thought- Now, at first sight, I
regarded this as a wonderful
coincidence, but I soon found
that I was entirely mistaken,
and was inclined to be vexed
for not arriving at a true
solution, at once- It only
goes to show, (what I have
all along contended for,) that
you and I think alike! Now
do congratulate me on this wonderful discovery!
Yet, after all; it is not very wonderful, for, I be-
lieve it is natural for you & me to entertain the
same thoughts- I simply want to be congratu-
lated for having so clearly established the
fact. Taken in this connection, it is rather re-
markable that your letter, although written on Fri-
day, did not reach me till Wednesday. So that,
all things considered, we will have to agree
to not disagree. In answer to your inquiries
concerning my health & the danger of contracting
Small-Pox, I am happy to tell you, my little
darling, that I am weighing 150 lbs, & to assure
you that I am in no danger of getting sick.
It is true that up to the present time, we have
had nine (9) cases of the disease on the Post, all
of which are confined to children, and although
I attend to them, I do not have the least fear of the
affection; and if I never have to your under-
go any severer trials than attending to
to a dozen cases of Small-Pox at a time for the rest of
my days, I shall be only too happy,
Suppose I should contract it! Ah! would you
be glad to welcome a poor, miserable, ugly being
back to Murfreesboro? I am ugly enough, at
present (not fishing for compliments, my darling)
to answer all useful purposes, but to have
this ugliness increased by a hundred horrible
pits on my face, would you not shudder and
turn away your gaze? What think you?
Pardon me for calling up these uninviting pic-
tures; and if you will excuse me, I'll seek a
more lively topic. I am not surprised to
learn, my darling E., that Prof. Sharpe is so gal-
lant- I knew his failing in this respect, & hence
took great pains to leaves you under the protec-
ting wing of so attentive a gentleman. You
need not thank me, my darling,- I am only too
happy, at all times, to look to your pleasure.
But really, when you tell me that you cannot
turn your head in church with-
out “catching the Professor's eye”,
really this is too much. It does
not astonish me, in the least,
that the Professor should look
at your, for during our long
acquaintance, he has often
confessed with blushes, & that
modesty which is so becoming,
that he could never resist
the temptation of looking at,
or to use his own language,
“of casting a sly peep at
a pretty girl-” In vain, has
he struggled to overcome this
tendency, but to no purpose have
his good efforts tended- Hence
that he should look at you; you
the prettiest girl that Mur-
freesboro ever boasted of,
among all her charming
damsels, this doesn't sur-
prise me; but that you should be looking
at the Professor so much, this is a little unex-
pected- Ah! I shall have to write to him & tell
him to take care or else some fair nymph
will entwine him in her net. I shall have
to tell him what the Poet has sung about
this very little village. I am inclined to think
that you have seen the quotation & will recognize it, at
once. Still it is just as applicable & to repeat it will
do no harm. This is what he said-

lg.l: Ah! thou hast daughters, my little village,
Whose daily task it is to pillage
And much I pity the heedless swain
Thinking that he'll be free again
What though he laughs at Cupid's dart;
So the rock laughs at the wave
That, swelling higher, bids it part
And he, full soon, will feel the power,
For though he were their king, this hour,

div1.p:
This, and much more, of
a like nature, I'll send him in order to put
him on his guard- But of this, more anon.
If Miss Annie Vaughan has arrived in your town,
please give her my very best regards & tell her to
be sure to stay till I come- Remember me kindly
to your Sister & mother- Believe me, my darling,
